slides.title: Introduction to Agentic Coding
slides.subtitle: Operator Training for AI Coding Agents

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: Welcome to Agentic Coding. This course is designed for senior engineers who've tried AI coding assistants and hit frustration walls. We're not here to teach AI theory—we're here to teach you how to operate these tools effectively in production.
speakerNotes.discussion: Quick show of hands: how many have tried AI coding assistants? How many felt frustrated within the first few weeks?
speakerNotes.context: AI coding assistants are production-standard in 2025. The technology works, but most developers struggle because they're using the wrong mental model.
speakerNotes.transition: Let's start by understanding why most developers get frustrated with AI coding assistants.

slides.title: The Reality of AI Coding in 2025
content: Companies ship features faster with them
Most developers hit frustration walls within weeks
The problem isn't the tools—it's the operating model

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: The technology works. Companies are shipping faster. But there's a pattern: developers get excited, try the tools, then hit a wall. They fight context limits, fix AI code line-by-line, and wait for the AI to 'understand.' That's the wrong approach entirely.
speakerNotes.discussion: What frustrations have you encountered? Common answers: context limits, wrong assumptions, code that doesn't compile, having to explain the same thing repeatedly.
speakerNotes.context: This frustration pattern is universal. It's not about skill level—senior engineers hit it too. The issue is treating AI like a junior developer instead of a tool.
speakerNotes.transition: The key insight is changing how you think about AI agents.

right.label: Correct Model
content: AI as CNC machine for code

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: AI agents aren't teammates—they're tools. Think CNC machine, not junior developer. You don't wait for a CNC machine to understand your intent. You give it precise specifications and it executes. Same principle applies here.
speakerNotes.discussion: Why is the 'junior developer' mental model so tempting? Because the interface is conversational. But conversation doesn't equal understanding.
speakerNotes.context: This shift is the foundation of everything else in the course. Without it, you'll keep fighting the tool instead of operating it.
speakerNotes.transition: So what does it mean to 'operate' an AI coding agent? Let's look at the core workflow.

slides.title: What This Course Is
content: Operator training for AI coding agents

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: This is operator training. We assume you already know how to engineer software. We're teaching you how to orchestrate agents that execute it autonomously. The techniques here come from production environments, not demos.
speakerNotes.discussion: What production concerns come to mind when using AI agents? Think: reliability, code quality, security, maintainability.
speakerNotes.context: The course targets senior engineers with 3+ years experience who've already tried AI assistants and want to move past the frustration phase.
speakerNotes.transition: The core methodology follows three phases.

slides.title: The Plan-Execute-Validate Workflow
content: Plan: Break work into agent-appropriate tasks
Plan: Research architecture, ground in context
Execute: Craft precise prompts, delegate to sub-agents
Validate: Tests as guardrails, critical review

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: Three phases: Plan, Execute, Validate. Planning means breaking work into chunks the agent can handle and grounding it in your codebase context. Execution means precise prompts and parallel delegation. Validation means tests and critical review—never trust output blindly.
speakerNotes.discussion: Which phase do you think most developers skip or rush? Usually it's planning—they jump straight to prompting without context.
speakerNotes.context: Each module of the course maps to these phases. Module 2 covers methodology, Module 3 covers practical techniques for each phase.
speakerNotes.transition: Let's be clear about what this course won't cover.

slides.title: What This Course Isn't
content: Not AI theory—just enough to operate effectively
Not for beginners without production experience

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: We cover AI internals only where they affect operation. Copying prompt templates doesn't work—understanding principles does. You still need architecture, design patterns, and system design knowledge. If you're a beginner, get production experience first.
speakerNotes.discussion: Why don't prompt templates work? Because every codebase is different. What works in one context fails in another. Principles adapt; templates don't.
speakerNotes.context: This is for engineers who already have the fundamentals. We're adding a new skill on top of existing expertise, not replacing it.
speakerNotes.transition: Who exactly is this course designed for?

slides.title: Target Audience
content: Already tried AI assistants, hit frustration points
Want speed without sacrificing code quality
Need efficient codebase understanding and debugging

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: You're in the right place if you have production experience, have tried these tools, and want to use them effectively. The frustration you've felt isn't failure—it's the starting point for learning the right approach.
speakerNotes.discussion: What brought you to this course specifically? What problems are you hoping to solve?
speakerNotes.context: The course assumes familiarity with software engineering concepts. We move fast and don't explain basics.
speakerNotes.transition: Here's what you'll be able to do after completing the course.

slides.title: What You'll Gain
content: Refactor complex features with test-driven validation
Debug production issues via agent delegation
Review code systematically with AI assistance
Plan and execute with parallel sub-agent delegation

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: Concrete outcomes: faster onboarding through agentic research, reliable refactoring with tests as guardrails, debugging by delegating log analysis, systematic code review, and parallel execution for complex features.
speakerNotes.discussion: Which of these outcomes matters most for your current work? That should guide which modules you focus on most.
speakerNotes.context: These aren't theoretical benefits. They're documented outcomes from production use of these techniques.
speakerNotes.transition: The most important skill you'll develop is judgment.

left.label: Ineffective Operator
content: Spends more time fixing AI output

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: The key differentiator is knowing when to use agents and when to write code yourself. Some tasks are faster manually. Some are perfect for agents. Effective operators make that call correctly. This judgment separates success from frustration.
speakerNotes.discussion: Can you think of tasks that seem like they'd be good for AI but actually aren't? Examples: highly novel problems, tasks requiring deep institutional knowledge.
speakerNotes.context: We'll develop this judgment throughout the course. It's not a rule set—it's a skill built through practice.
speakerNotes.transition: Let's cover the prerequisites before diving in.

slides.title: Prerequisites
content: Tools: Access to a CLI coding agent
Recommended: Claude Code for plan mode and sub-agents

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: You need real experience—these techniques build on engineering fundamentals. You need access to a CLI agent like Claude Code, OpenAI Codex, or Copilot CLI. And you need to be willing to change your mental model.
speakerNotes.discussion: Which tool are you using? The principles apply across tools, but some features like plan mode and sub-agents are tool-specific.
speakerNotes.context: Claude Code is recommended at time of writing for its plan mode, sub-agents, slash commands, and hierarchical CLAUDE.md support.
speakerNotes.transition: Here's how the course is structured.

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: Three modules that build on each other. Start with fundamentals to get the mental model right. Then methodology for the how. Then practical techniques for real-world application. Don't skip the exercises—reading alone won't build the skill.
speakerNotes.discussion: Have you worked through technical courses before without doing the exercises? How did that work out?
speakerNotes.context: Work through exercises on real codebases, not the examples provided. The goal is building transferable skill, not completing a tutorial.
speakerNotes.transition: One note about how this course was created.

slides.title: Course Development: Practicing What We Teach
content: Entire curriculum developed using these techniques
Planned, researched, drafted via systematic prompting
Validated through agentic research and iteration
Podcast episodes generated via Claude Code + Gemini

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: This course was built using the same techniques it teaches. Every module was planned with agents, grounded in research, and validated critically. Even the podcast versions are AI-generated. If these techniques can produce production-grade training material, they're robust enough for your codebase.
speakerNotes.discussion: Does knowing the course was AI-assisted change how you think about it? This is the transparency principle in action.
speakerNotes.context: The voices in the podcast (Alex and Sam) are AI-generated. The scripts were created through the same workflow you'll learn.
speakerNotes.transition: Let's wrap up with the key takeaways before you start Lesson 1.

slides.title: Key Takeaways
content: AI agents are tools, not teammates

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: Four things to remember: First, shift your mental model from teammate to tool. Second, follow the three-phase workflow. Third, develop judgment about when to use agents. Fourth, do the exercises—skill comes from practice, not reading.
speakerNotes.discussion: What's one thing from this introduction that challenged an assumption you had about AI coding assistants?
speakerNotes.context: These takeaways form the foundation for everything else in the course. Return to them when you hit frustration.
speakerNotes.transition: Ready to start? Begin with Lesson 1: LLMs Demystified, where we'll cover just enough AI internals to operate effectively.
